results.title: More Small Companies Avoid I.P.O.s, Sapping U.S. Economy’s Vitality
results.abstract: Small and midsize firms are increasingly steering clear of going public, giving big companies outsize influence over stock markets and hampering business creation, wage growth and productivity.
results.byline: By ERIN GRIFFITH and MATT PHILLIPS

multimedia.caption: Bill McDermott, the chief executive of SAP, in sunglasses, and Ryan Smith, the chief executive of Qualtrics, rang the closing bell in November at the New York Stock Exchange. Qualtrics agreed to sell itself to SAP rather than go through with a planned initial public offering.

results.title: A Hot Seat for Facebook, an Empty Chair for Zuckerberg and a Vow to Share Secret Files
results.abstract: At a hearing in London, officials from nine countries criticized the social network and said they planned to release internal Facebook documents soon.

multimedia.caption: A chair and the name plate for Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg who was invited to give evidence, and declined the invitation, to the Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee investigation into disinformation and fake news at the Houses of Parliament in London on November 27, 2018.

results.title: Jack Ma, China’s Richest Man, Belongs to the Communist Party. Of Course.
results.abstract: Many business figures join the organization out of expedience. Likewise, the party sees benefits in associating itself with capitalist success stories.

results.title: How to Survive the Next Era of Tech (Slow Down and Be Mindful)
results.abstract: In his final State of the Art column, Farhad Manjoo reflects on the industry’s changes and presents a new guide for navigating the future of technology.

results.title: New Zealand Blocks Huawei, in Blow to Chinese Telecom Giant
results.abstract: The announcement came a day after Papua New Guinea said it would uphold a deal with Huawei, illustrating the growing global divide over the risks of Chinese technology.

multimedia.caption: New Zealand rejected a proposal to use technology from Huawei, the Chinese telecom giant, to build its next-generation mobile data network, citing “significant national security risks.”

results.title: General Kicked Off Facebook Can Still Glorify Military at Grandiose Museum
results.abstract: The colossal museum built by Myanmar’s military to honor itself and its leader showcases the mind-set of a force obsessed with its reputation. A critic calls it “a sign of their megalomania.”

multimedia.caption: In an exhibition recounting Myanmar’s martial history, the portrait of Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing hangs at the top of a pyramid of military leaders.

results.title: How Cheap Labor Drives China’s A.I. Ambitions
results.abstract: If China is the Saudi Arabia of data, its data factories are the refineries, turning raw data into the fuel that can power China’s goal of A.I. supremacy.

multimedia.caption: Workers at the headquarters of Ruijin Technology Company in Jiaxian, in central China’s Henan Province. They identify objects in images to help artificial intelligence make sense of the world.

results.title: Amazon Lifts Ban on Australians Shipping From Its Main Site
results.abstract: The online retailer will make products from its main website available, reversing a decision that angered its customers earlier this year.

results.title: How Facebook’s P.R. Firm Brought Political Trickery to Tech
results.abstract: Definers, an import from Washington to Silicon Valley, thrived with opposition research and a fishy campaign to push Apple’s C.E.O. for president.

results.title: 5 Reasons Cryptocurrency Prices Are Plunging Again
results.abstract: A year ago, Bitcoin and other digital currencies were booming. Here’s why things look so much bleaker now.

multimedia.caption: A Bitcoin facility in Quebec. Cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin were supposed to help solve real-world problems, but so far the real world hasn’t had much use for them.

results.title: James H. Billington, 89, Dies; Led Library of Congress Into Digital Age
results.abstract: Overseeing the nation’s treasure house of knowledge for three decades, he almost doubled its holdings but resigned in 2015, stung by cries of mismanagement.

multimedia.caption: James H. Billington in 1989. He led the Library of Congress for nearly three decades, taking over at the dawn of the digital era.

results.title: Record and Share Your Family History in 5 Steps
results.abstract: Holiday gatherings offer a great time to create a multimedia digital archive of interviews with your relatives so they can share their memories with the current — and future — branches of the tree.

results.title: You Don’t Have to Be a Journalist to Want to Keep Chats Private
results.abstract: It’s easy to leave behind digital evidence when talking to sources — or to friends. Here’s how Kate Conger, a tech reporter, reduces that exposure.

results.title: Somali Workers in Minnesota Force Amazon to Negotiate
results.abstract: Labor organizers and researchers said they had not heard of Amazon previously coming to the table after worker pressure, even for private discussions.

results.title: The ‘Neo-Banks’ Are Finally Having Their Moment
results.abstract: High fees and low interest rates have provided an opening for a new generation of finance start-ups to compete with the big banks.

multimedia.caption: Chime, part of a new wave of alternative banks, has opened two million fee-free online checking accounts. Other so-called neo-banks include Aspiration, Empower and Varo.

results.title: How to Get the Most Out of Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Even if You’re Not Into Tech)
results.abstract: Black Friday and Cyber Monday may be known for hot gadgets and electronics, but there are great deals on other things, too. Here are a few to watch out for.

results.title: Missed Connection or Canceled Flight? 6 Tips for Getting What You Want From an Airline
results.abstract: Tips for using social media effectively when you are trying to resolve a travel disaster, from a canceled flight to a missed connection.
